p.seg: The gù (reason/cause) of something
is what it must get before it will come about.
E. 'Minor reason':
having this, it will not necessarily be so;
lacking this, necessarily it will not be so.
It is the unit[which precedes all others(?)]
(Like having a starting-point.)
'Major reason':
having this, it will necessarily [be so]:
lacking [this, necessarily it will not] be so.
(Like the appearing bringing about the seeing.)
A tǐ (unit/individual/part)
is a portion of a jiān (total/collection/whole).
E. (For example, one of two,
or the starting-point of a measured length.)
C. THE "INTELLIGENCE':
is the capability.
E. The 'intelligence': it being the means by which one knows, one necessarily does know.
(Like the eyesight.)
C. Lyù (thinking/forethought)
is the seeking.
E. 'Thinking':
by means of one's intelligence one seeks something
but does not necessarily find it.
(Like peering.)
C. Zhī (knowing) is the connecting.
'Knowing':
E. by means of one's intelligence, having passed the thing one is able to describe it.
(Like seeing.)
C. Zhì (understanding/wisdom) is the illumination.
'Understanding':
E. by means of one's intelligence, in discourse about the thing
one's knowedge of it is apparent.
(Like clearness of sight.)
C. To be rén (benevolent/humane.kind)
is to love individually.
E. Love of oneself
is not for the same of making oneself useful.
(Not like loving a horse.)
C. To be yì (righteous/dutiful/moral)
is to benefit.
E. In intent, he takes the whole world as his field;
in ability, he is able to benefit it.
He is not necessarily employed.
C. Lǐ (manners/courtesy)
is respect.
E. The noble are addressed as 'Sir',
the base by their given names,
but in both cases one may be either respectful or rude,
because modes of behaviour are different for different ranks.
C. Xíng (conduct)
is doing.
E. What one does, neutrally named,
is one's conduct.
Giving a good name to what one does
is trickery.
(For example, to committing robbery.)
C. To be chéng (sincere/whole-hearted)
is to reveal oneself spontaneously.
The manifestation of his intent and his zeal
enables others to know him.
(Not like the tinkle of metal or jade pendants.)
C. To be zhōng (to serve loyally/do ones utmost)
is to be energetic in sustaining the responsibility when one deems something beneficial.
C. To be xiào (filial)
is to benefit one's parents.
E. In intent, he takes his parents as his field;
in ability, he is able to benefit them.
He does not necessarily succeed.
C. Xìn (good faith/trustworthiness)
is the words agreeing with the thoughs.
E. It is not by his words fitting the fact that he makes others pay attention to them,
it is because they are sure of his conduct.
The frankness of his owrds
enables others to verify them.
(...the city wall and get the money.)
C. To sī (be in authority(?))
is to act on one's own initiative.
E. When he confronts aother,
the multitude follows his lead.
C. To be juān (scrupulous/squeamish)
is to be deficient in initiative.
E. He does the right things;
but when doing the right thing interferes with someother thing,
he will not do it.
C. To be lián (honest/conscientious)
is to (...?) initiates.
E. Although he performs it himself,
it is ??under the authority of someone who knows the rest about it(?)
C. To lìng (command)
is not to perform what one initiates.
E. It is not that he is not himself the agent. [It is by no means that in person he refuses to put it into practice. CH]
C. Rén *bearing the weight of a responsibility)
is an officer working to his own loss but to the advantage of those on whose behalf he acts.
E. He performs what in his own interests he dislikes in order to bring about what others need.
C. Yōng (courage)
is that by which intent is daring.
E. One names a man 'brave' because of what he does dare;
one does not raise as an objection something else that he does not dare.
C. Lì (strength)
is that by which the body exerts itself.
E. It is of eight what it is said.
Lifting weight from below
is exertion.
C. Shēng (life)
is the body being located with the intelligence.
C. Wò (sleep)
is the intelligence not knowing of anything.
C. Mèng (dreaming)
is supposing to be so while asleep.
C. Píng (calm)
is the intelligence neither desiring nor disliking anything.
E... tranquil.
C. Lì (benefit)
is what one is pleased to get.
E. If you are pleased to get this one,
this is the beneficial one,
and the harmful one is not this one.
C. Hài (harm)
is what one dislikes getting.
E. If you dislike getting this one
this is the harmful one,
and the one which is beneficial is not this one.
C. Zhì/chí (deal with successfully/put in order)
is to achieve what is sought. [Lit: 1. What is sought is one achieves. 2. is a trying and an achieving]
E. One's own affairs having been put in order,
others also putting in order North and South ...
C. Yù,
is to make plain what is honourable.
C. To fěi (blame)
is to make plain what is dishonourable.
C. Jǔ (torefer to/pick out by name from others)
is to present the analogue for the object.
E. For 'like the stone', one necessarily uses what is like the name. [Not "like" but "in accordance with] CH
C. Yán (to say/speak of/words)
is to emit references. [is to pick out/make choices CH]
E. To inform about this name
is to refer to the other object [bǐ is not "other": that object (not identical with the name) CH]
Therefore 'saying'
is an emitting of something's characteristics of which any speaker is capable.
'If the characteristics are like the picture,
it is a tiger'
is saying.
To say that which it is called (as in the case of 'stone'),
is to communicate it.
C. Qiě (will/about to)
is declaring something to be so ?before the event?.
E. Before the event one says "about to",
after the event one says 'already'.
The just now so too is about to be.
(??Like "I'm afraid it will", and "let's for the moment".??)
C. The jūn (ruler)
is the common knot tying ministers and people.
C. Gōng (achievement)
is benefiting the people.
E. If not at the due time,
even if it is beneficial there is no achievement.
(Like summer and winter clothes.)
p.note: 不待時："if without waiting for the appropriate time one simply benefits, that is not a '(meritorious) contribution'."
衣 are not "summer clothes" just "ordinary clothes", as opposed to "cloaks for the winter"

p.seg: C. Shǎng (reward)
is requital from above for achievement below.
C. Zuì (crime)
is violation of a prohibition.
E. If not covered by a prohibition,
even if it is harmful there is no crime.
C. Fá (punishment)
is requital from above for crime below.
C. Tóng (agreeing/conforming)
is being different but both the same in relation to this one thing.
E. They are two men but both see that this is a pillar.
(Like serving a ruler.)
??The pillar's engendering of the complement is not to be treated as necessary.??
C. Jiǔ (duration)
is pervasion of different times.
E. 'Present' and 'past' combine mornings and evenings.
C. Yǔ (space/extension)
is pervasion of different places.
E. 'East and West' covers North and South.
C. The qióng (limit)
is wherever at the next advance there is no room for a measured length.
E. If somewhere there is no room for a measured length,
it is limited; [there is the a limit CH]
if everywhere there is room for a measured length,
it is limitless [there is no limit CH].
C. Jìn (exhausting/applying to all/all)
is none not being so.
E. Something is fixed of all of them.
C. Shǐ (commence)
is to be plumb with the time.
E. Of times of a movement,
there is one which has duration
and one without duration.
The commencement is plumb with the one without duration.
C. Huà (transformation)
is the distinguishing marks of one thing changing to the distinguishing marks of another.
E. (For example, a frog becoming a quail.)
C. Sǔn (reduction/loss)
is the removal of some without the rest.
E. 'Some but not the rest':
it is a unit in a total.
Of its units, if one is removed and the other remains,
we say that the one which remains is reduced.
C. To xuán (circle round)
is to ??swerve??.
E. It is the figure of a curve.
To yùn (rotate)
is to change round.
E. The circumference is like a cut,
the figure is constant.
C. Dòng (to stir move)
is to shift somewhere.
E. Things which shift all over the border:
the hinge of a door,
??the louse on a hare??.
C. Zhǐ (to stay/remain fixed)
is to endure as it was.
E. When the one without duration does not stay,
the thing fits 'ox' and 'non-horse'.
(Like the arrowing passing the starting-post.)
When the one which has duration does not stay,
the thing fits 'horse' and 'non-horse'.
(Like a man having passed over a bridge.)
C. Bì (the necessary/the certain)
is the unending.
E. It is said of cases where complements are 'matured.'
(For example, younger-brother and elder-brother.)
Of a thing so in one case,
a thing not so in one case
??that it stays as such?? is unnecessary, [not necessary CH]
that it is this or is not is necessary.
Píng (level/flat)
is of the same height.
C. Tóng cháng (of the same length)
is each when laid stgraight exhausting the other.
E. The same lengths or door-bar and door-frame are straight.
C. The zhōng (centre) is
(??the place from which??) they are the same in length.
E. Distances outward from this
are alike.
C. Hòu (having bulk/thickness/dimension)
is having something than which it is bigger.
E. Only (??the starting-point) has nothing than which it is bigger.
C. Rì zhōng (the sun at the centre/noon)
is the sun being due South.
C. Zhí (straight/on a straight course)
is in alignment.
C. Yuán (circular)
is having the same lengths from one centre.
E. The compasses draw it ??in the rough??.
C. Fāng (square)
is ??circuiting?? in four from a ??right angle??
E. The carpenter's square shows it ??in the rough??.
C. Bèi (doubling)
is making two of them.
E. When they are two,
measured foot and measured foot both depart from one starting-point,
which is being nowhere the same.
C. Duān (starting-point)
is the unit without dimension which precedes all others.
C. Yǒu jiān (having an interval/discontinuous)
is (not extending to) the centre.
E. It refers to the flanking ones.
C. Jiān (intervening/in between)
is not extending to the sides.
E. It refers to what is flanked.
Lengths measured from starting-point to circumference are not flanked by starting-point and circumference.
Thetwo extensions are estensions of which it is not the case that they come out level with each other.
is the interval being empty.
E. Empty: of the interval between the two pieces of wood,
it refers to where there is no wood.
C. To yíng (fill) [fill out CH]
is to be nowhere absent.
E. What does not fill anything is dimensionless.
Along a measured length wherever you go you find the two.
C. Jiān bái (as hard to white/mutually pervasive)
is not excluding each other
E. Different positions do not fill each other.
Not being each other is excluding each other.
C. Yīng (touching/coinciding)
is occupying each other.
E. Of measured feet neither is wholly covered by the other.
Of starting-points, each is wholly covered by the other.
Of the measured foot and the starting-point, one is wholly covered and the other is not.
The hard and the white in conciding wholly cover each other.
Countable units in coinciding do not wholly cover each other.
C. Bi (side by side/measured against each other/commensurate)
is over part of the length coinciding
and over part of it not.
E. It is possible only if both proceed from a starting-point.
C. Cì (the next/adjacent)
is without interval but not coinciding.
E. It is possible only because the starting-point is dimensionless.
C. The fǎ (standard)
is that in being like which something is so.
E. The idea, the compasses, a circle,
all three may serve as standard.
C. The yīn (criterion)
is that wherein it is so.
E. Being'so'
is the characteristics being like the standard.
C. Shuō (explaining/demonstrating)
is the means by which one makes plain.
C. Fǎn (being the converse of each other)
is if inadmissable then on both sides inadmissible.
E. All oxen,
and non-oxen marked off as a group,
are the two sides.
To lack what distinguishes an ox is to be a non-ox.
C. Biàn (disputation)
is contending overclaims which are the converse of each other.
Winning in disputation
is fitting the fact.
E. One calling it 'ox'
and the other 'non-ox'
is 'contending over claims which are the converse of each other'.
Such being the case they do not both fit the fact;
and if they do not both fit,
necessarily one of thejm does not fit.
(Not like fitting 'dog'.)
C. To wèi (to be doing something for the sake of..../to have as an end)
is to give the most weight in relation to the desires having taken account of all that one knows.
E. If you prefer to cut off your finger,
and the understanding does not recognise the harm in it,
this is the understanding being at fault.
If the consideration paid to it by the understanding
overlooks none of the harm in it,
but you still prefer to cut it off,
then that things have turned out unhappily
is as with eating dried meat.
E. (Continued)Whether putrid meat will benefit or harm is unknowable in advance;
if you prefer to eat the meat and it is putrid,
then eating it
is refusing to take the doubt as grounds for fixing which you prefer.
Whether there was benefit or harm 'beyond the wall' was not knowable in advance;
if by heading for it you could get money,
then refusing tohead for it
would be taking the doubt as grounds for fixing which you prefer.
In the light of the principle that "To be 'for' is to give most weight in relation to the desires, having taken account of all that one knows,
when you cut up dried meat it is not wisdom,
when you cut off a finger it is not foolishness.
When what your are for and what you are against put each other in doubt
you are failing to plan things out.
C. Yǐ (end/finish).
To bring about,
to get rid of.
E. Of making a coat:
'to bring about'.
Of curing an illness:
'to get rid of'.
C. Shǐ (to commission/to cause)
To tell.
The cause.
E. To give orders
is 'to tell'.
The thing does not necessarily come about.
Dampness
is a cause.
It is necessarily required that what it does comes about.
C. Míng (name).
Unrestricted: classifying: private. [Strange punctuation! CH]
E. 'Thing' is 'unrestricted;
any object necessarily requires this name. [If there is an object... CH]
Naming something 'horse' is 'classifying';
for 'like the object'
we necessarily use this name.
Naming someone 'Jack' is'private';
this name stays confined to this object.
The sounds which issue from the mouth all have a name.
(For example, surname and style-name.)
C. Wèi (call).
Transfer, refer, apply.
E. Of naming by linking 'whelp' and 'dog':
'transfer'.
Of 'whelp',
of 'dog':
'refer'.
Of hooting at a dog:
'apply'. [direct oneself towards, address CH]
C. Zhī (know).
By hearsay,, by explanation, by personal experience.
The name, the object, how to relate, how to act.
E. Having received it at second hand is knowing by 'hearsay'.
Knowing that something square will not rotate is by 'explanation' .
Having been a witness oneself is knowing 'by personal experience'.
What something is called by is its 'name'.
What is so called is the object.
The matingof name and object is 'relating'.
To intend and to perform are to 'act'.
C. Wén (hear).
At second hand, in person.
E. Being told byh someone
is hearing 'at second hand'.
Being a witness oneself
is hearing 'in person'.
C. Jiàn (see)
Individuals, all.
E. ??One member of a pair?? is an 'individual'.
The pair of them are 'all'.
C. Hé (relation/tallying/being together).
Exact, to the one whichis appropriate, necessary.
E. The relations of ??sharing a level with, coinciding as the converse??,aim and achievement,
are 'exact'.
The relation to what Jack is deemed to be is 'to the one which is appropriate'.
If without something else something is necessarily absent, the relation is 'necessary'.
The judgments of sages, employ but do not treat as necessary.
The necessary, accept and do not doubt.
The ones which are the converse of each other, apply on both sides, not on one without the other.
C. Yù (desire/be about to).
Directly,
weighing the benfit:
be about to.
Wù (dislike).
Directly,
weighing the harm.
C. Wéi (constitute/become/deem/make/cure/govern/.
Keep as it is, get rid of, exchange, dissolve, govern, transform.
E. Of ??coinciding with a complement??: keep as it is.
Of illness: 'get rid of'.
Of buying and selling: 'exchange'.
Of sleet or ashes: 'dissolve'.
Of instructing and leading: 'govern'.
Of frog and quail: 'transform'.
C. Tóng (same).
Identical, as units, as together, of a kind.
E. There being two names but one object
is the sameness of 'identity'.
Not being outside the total
is the sameness 'as units'.
Both occupying the room
is the sameness of being 'together'.
Being the same in some respect
is sameness in being 'of that kind'.
C. Yì (different).
Two, not units, not together, not of a kind.
E. The objectgs if the names are two necessarily being different
is being 'two'.
Not connected or attached
is 'not units'.
Not in the same place
is 'not together'.
Not the same in a certain respect [one wishes the text did say that, indeed...CH]
is 'not of a kind'.
C. Sameness and difference.
In interplay the following become relative:
having and lacking, more and less, departing and approaching,
hard and soft, dead and alive elder and younger.
On both sides the following prevail decisively:
being this or not being it (/right or wrong), proved or not yet proved, both being complements,
present or absent, surname or the thing itself, dear or cheap.
E. In interprlay the following become relative:
In the case of a rich family, of native intelligence, 'having and lacking'.
In the case of putting side by side and measuring,
'more and less'.
In the case of ??a louse on a hare moving this way and that??, '
departing and approaching.
In the case of ??retreating the better to attack??,
hard and soft.
In the case of ??a sword just striking??,
'dead and alive'.
In the case of son, son and mother within a family,
'elder and younger'.
E. (CONTINUED)On both sides the following prevaildecisively:
white or black, centre or side.
In the case of discourse, conduct, learning, an object, "being this or not being it (/right or wrong)'.
In the casse of raising objections to a proposal or ??putting off acting on it?? proved or not yet proved.
In the case of elder-brother and younger-brother, both being complements'.
In the case of the body being here and the thoughts on something elsewhere, 'present or absent'.
In the case of what 'Crane' constitutes, 'the surname or the thing as it is in itself'.
In the case of a price being right, 'dear or cheap'.

C. An assent and a denial are one in the benefit and the use.
E. When we 'jump the wall', the circular stays fixed.
Byh the things which follow from each other or exclude eachother,
we may know 'a priori' what it is.
For the five colours, long and short, before and after, light and heavy
adduce the one to which you are committed.
C. When someone devotes himself to a commitment,
if the description takes a subtle turn
seek his reasons.
E. If he raises objections to an established statement,
and makes it his business to establish this commitment,
seek the standard for the commitment.
C. If the standard is the same
examine what is the same in it.
E. Choose what is the same,
and examine the subtle turn.
C. If the standard differes,
examine what is appropriate to it.
E. Choose this and pick out that
ask about reasons and examine appropriateness.
Using what is black and what is not blakck in a man to fix 'black man',
and using love to some men and failure to love other men to fix 'love of man' -
of these which is appropriate?
C. Fix the criterion in order to 'separate the roads'.
E. If the other man, referring to a respect in which it is so, deems it so in the instance here,
refer to respects in which it is not so and inquire about them.
(For example, the sage has respects in which he is not, yet he is.
C. The exact nowhere is not.
E. the matching and the assent enter the consciousness together.
When something is explained, and you assent to more than that they match
(for example, to a circle being nowhere straight),
or nothing is explained and you assent on the basis of the matching,
it is as though it were so of itself.xxx
C. Fix the kind, in order to 'make the man proceed'.
Explained by: the sameness.
E. The other, on the grounds that it is soof the instance here,
argues that is so of the thing it is;
I, on the grounds that it is not so of the instance here,
doubt that it is so of the thing it is.
p.note: 我：this is a neat case of impersonal use of the first person pronoun in the context of "the other party" versus "ONE's own party".

p.seg: C. When fours are different,
explain the difficultyu of extending from kind to kind.
Explained by: fixing 'the wider and the narrower, 'all of the thing'.
E. If we say it has four feet
is it an animal? Or a living thing, or a bird? -
'all of the thing' and 'the wider and the narrower.
If what is so of the instance here were necessarily so of a thing that it is,
all would be milu deer.
C. With the same name, of 'are two' and 'fight', 'loves', 'eats' and 'summons', 'is white' and 'is blind',
or with others as linked to them,
of 'husband' and 'shoes',
we discard one of the pair,
yet inherently the thing is what we called it.
Explained by: the criterion.
E. They both fight', 'they are not both two' (are two and fight).
... ('Eats' and 'summons')
'MOST of a white horse is white',
'MOST of a blind horse is not blind.
('is white' and 'is blind').
When deemings are linked
we cannot treat it as necessary either that they are of a kind
or that they conflict.
What is deemed fēi (not-this),
if you link rén shì with it (rén shì fēi 'others' approval or blame)
is not being deemed not-this.
For example, someone deemed a fū (husband),
when you link yōng with it (yōng fū 'brave man')
is not being deemed a husband.
But something deemed ju (shoes),
when you link mǎi yī with it (mǎi yī ju 'buy coat and shoes') IS being deemed a pair of shoes.
('Husband' and 'shoes').
Being two is lost with the one that is lost,
does not remain with the one that remains.
Whether or not we are dropping "They are two',
only when there are these objects is it said of them,
without these objects it is not said.
It is not like 'flower' and 'beautiful'.
If 'beautiful' is said of this, then inherently it is this that is beautiful;
if it is said of another, it is not the case that this is beautiful;
and if it is not said of it the converse applies.
C. Even when one cannot be dropped without the other they are two.
Explained by: seeing and appearing,
one and two,
length and breadth.
E. Seeing and appearing are apart,
one and two do not fill each other,
length and breadth are 'as-hard-to-white'.
C. It is no objection that one is unable.
Explaineed by: the full range of our capacities.
E. To lift a heavy thing
but fail to lift a needle
is not something for which one's strength is held responsible.
Whether being deemed a complement is one-sided or double
is not something for which the understanding is held responsible.
(Like the ears and eyes.)
Different kinds are not comparable.
Explained by measuring.
E. Which is longer, a piece of wood or a night?
Which do you have more of, knowledge or grain?
Which is the most valuable, aristocratic rank, one's own parents, right conduct, a price?
Which is higher, a deer or a crane?
Which is more *G'K (sleek), a deer or a *G'K (crane)?
Which is more *{SIET} (glossy), a *{SIET} (louse) or a *{SIET} (zither). [See Graham for transcriptions]
C. When one or other is dropped there is no reduction of the things.
Explained by: the things as they inherently are.
E. In both being as one nothing has altered.
C. To loan-name is necessarily self-contradictory.
Explained by: not being so of it.
E. What it is loan-named it necessarily is not, otherwise it would not be a loan-name.
When a dog is loan-named as a being a crane, [as a 'crane' CH]
it is as when one gives it the clan-name 'Crane'.
C. Why a thing is so,
and how I know it,
and how I make others know it,
are not necessarily the same.
Explained by sickness.
E. That someone has wounded him
is why it is so. [...and we wish the text had said this...CH]
That I saw it,
is how I kow.
That I tell them
is how I make others know.
C. Doubt.
Explained by accidental, easy, coinciding or transient circumstances.
E. IN A DENSE MIST MISTAKING AMAN FOR AN OX??,
the dweller in a booth being cold in summer:
'accidental circumstances'.
To lift things when they are light
and put them down when they are heavy
is not a test of strength.
(for example, stone and feathers),
p.note: lines seven to nine: Note the extraordinary disregard for word order and grammar in lines seven and eight. This needs further study.

p.seg: to shave wood along the grain
is not a test of skill.
[MOVED TO LAST PAGE]
Whether a fighter's breakdown
is due to drining wine or to the midday sun
cannot be known:
'coinciding circumstances'.
Is it knowing?
Or is it supposing the already ended to be so?:
'transient circumstances'.
C. Together or one thing:
in the former case one adds name to name, in the other not.
Explained by: marking off as a group.
E. You put together 'water and earth',
and from 'a fire and a fire' separate 'a fire';
you put together these fǔ (water, earth, fire),
and from 'the wood and the wood' separate 'the wood;
it depends only on convenience.
(For example, noting the numbers of the deer and the fish.)
C. Things marked off as a group are one unit.
Explained by: both being as one, being this thing specifically.
E. 'Both being as one': for example, 'oxen and horses have four feet'.
'Being this thing specifically: they fit 'ox' or 'horse'.
If you count oxen as an item and horses as an item,
oxen and horses are two.
If you count oxen and horses as an item
oxen and horses are one.
(For example, counting the fingers.
The fingers are five, but the five are one.)
C. Space travels in a certain direction.
Explained by: growing older.
E. Growing older, one travels and again occupies space
